lead_paragraph: In New York, the National Weather Service said 26.8 inches of snow had fallen on Central Park by midnight, making this the city’s second-biggest snowstorm since 1869.

byline.contributor: Reporting was contributed by Nicholas Fandos and Sheryl Gay Stolberg in Washington; Jon Hurdle in Ocean City, N.J.; and Michael Barbaro, Mark S. Getzfred, Andy Newman, Emily Palmer, Noah Remnick, Nate Schweber, Liam Stack, John Surico and Jonathan Wolfe in New York.
byline.original: By JAMES BARRON and RICK ROJAS

headline.print_headline: Swirling Storm Draws White Curtain Over East
headline.main: Major Cities Grind to a Halt and Face Days of Digging Out Snow

snippet: In New York, the National Weather Service said 26.8 inches of snow had fallen on Central Park by midnight, making this the city’s second-biggest snowstorm since 1869.
abstract: Major snowstorm descends on East Coast, dumping over two feet of snow in some areas, halting traffic and bringing several large cities to standstill; New York and at least nine other states declare state of emergency, while New York City issues travel ban.
